<h3 class="heading A-TYP16R-RW-ALL " id="content_main_heading_2">
    </h3><h3><strong>What affects the value of money?</strong></h3>

</div>

        
    
        
        
            
            
            
            
            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="content_main_richtext_2" class=" A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Money has a tendency to lose its value over time because the price of goods and services has an upward tendency. This is called inflation. Here are some factors that could eat away your money:</p> 
<ul class="A-LSTU-RW-ALL"> 
 <li>Inflation. Simply, inflation occurs when the price of goods and services rises. And when prices rise, people will ask for a rise in salary. That's why the money you earn today will be worth less 10 years from now.</li> 
 <li>Interest rate fluctuations. A drop in interest rates means a smaller return on your deposits, and if the interest rate is lower than the rate of inflation, your savings lose value. But for some investments, such as equities and bonds, the value of your investment may rise because of the drop in interest rates.</li> 
</ul> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Therefore it is crucial that you have a financial plan to protect your future and to put your money where it generates reasonable returns to meet your needs.</p>
</div></div>

    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What types of financial tools can I invest my money in?</strong><br> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">You can choose from a range of different financial tools:<br> </p> 
<ul class="A-LSTU-RW-ALL"> 
 <li>HKD, RMB and foreign currency savings and time deposits<br> </li> 
 <li><a href="https://www.hsbc.com.hk/personal/investments.html">Investments products</a></li> 
 <li><a href="https://www.hsbc.com.hk/personal/insurance.html">Insurance products</a></li> 
</ul> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Traditionally, savings or time deposits are the safest place to put your money, but often offer lower rates of interest. Investment products usually offer potentially higher returns but with a greater risk.<br> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>How can I set up an investment account?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">You can open an investment account online in most circumstances. You must maintain a personal banking account with HSBC before s/he can open an investment account online.<br> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Alternatively you can also open an investment account at our branches. If you wish to open a joint account, you can only do so at our branches.<br> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Is there any fee to be charged?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Opening an investment account does not incur any fees. However, there may be other account fees applicable depending on the nature of the account and the products held in the account. Besides, there may be transaction fees involved when you buy or sell investment products. Please consult our staff should you have any queries.<br> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What is Financial Product and what is not?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Financial Product is a term defined in the Code of Conduct for Persons Licensed by or Registered with the Securities and Futures Commission. <h3 class="heading A-TYP16R-RW-ALL " id="content_main_heading_3">
    </h3><h3><strong>What are bonds?</strong></h3>

</div>

        
    
        
        
            
            
            
            
            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="content_main_richtext_5" class=" A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Bonds are credit notes issued by governments, corporations or other issuers to bondholders. As a bondholder, you are extending credit to these issuers and they are obligated to repay the redemption value of the bond upon maturity, as well as a rate of interest during the life of the bond. There are many types of bonds from different issuers that vary in their terms. Some examples include the fixed rate bond, floating rate bond, zero coupon bond and convertible bond as well as Certificates of Deposit (CDs).<br>
In general, bonds and CDs offer comparatively safe returns. At HSBC, we currently offer bonds and CDs issued by governments including PRC, US and HKSAR, local quasigovernment bodies, supranationals and well-known corporations around the world denominated in major currencies. There is also a wide selection of tenors or terms from which to choose, i.e., from 1 to 30 years with various benchmark yields. The minimum investment amount can be as low as HKD10,000.<br>
</p>

            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="content_main_richtext_6" class=" A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>How can I benefit from bond investments?</strong><br> </p> 
<ul class="A-LSTU-RW-ALL"> 
 <li>Regular income<br> Bonds deliver stable and predictable coupons as streams of income. Bonds also offer predictable repayment of principal at maturity.</li> 
 <li>Yield Enhancement<br> Bond yields are usually higher than time deposit rates with similar maturity.</li> 
 <li>Capital Gain Potential<br> You can also benefit from capital appreciation if bond prices move up.</li> 
 <li>Risk Diversification Tool<br> Bonds exhibit low correlation to other asset classes, hence the inclusion of bonds can bring relative stability to a portfolio.</li> 
</ul> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What types of bond are available through HSBC?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">HSBC offers you a full range of investment grade or equivalent bonds including RMB dimsum bonds, Government Bonds and Corporate Bonds with wide ranges of major currencies selections and tenors ranging from 1 to 30 years. Investment amount can be as low as HKD10,000.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Bonds from HSBC can be categorised by:</p> 
<ul class="A-LSTU-RW-ALL"> 
 <li>types of issuers - corporate bonds, supranational bonds and government/quasi-government bonds</li> 
 <li>coupon - fixed rate bonds, floating rate bonds and zero-coupon bonds</li> 
 <li>credit quality - investment grade bonds</li> 
 <li>currency - HKD, USD, AUD, CAD, CNY, EUR, GBP, NZD and SGD</li> 
</ul> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Do I need a large sum of money to invest in bonds?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">HSBC lets you invest in a wide range of bonds with a minimum investment amount of HK$10,000<sup>++</sup>.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><em></em><sup>++</sup>Please note the minimum and incremental investment amount varies from bond to bond. Please consult us for more details.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>How can I trade bonds with HSBC?</strong><br> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">You can now trade bonds via HSBC Online Banking or the HSBC HK Mobile Banking app. Our one-stop online platform offers bond IPO subscription and secondary market trading services.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">If you already have an HSBC Investment Services/Securities account, you can simply log on and execute your bond order with us. We also offer bond trading services through our branches and investment phonebanking service. To open an Investment Services/Securities account, simply apply through HSBC HK Mobile Banking app any time or visit any HSBC branch in Hong Kong.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Do I have to hold bonds until maturity?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">HSBC will repurchase the bonds purchased through us based on the prevailing market price under normal circumstances thus you may not hold the bonds until maturity. Customer's selling price may differ from the original buying price due to changes in market condition. You could lose part or all of your investment if you choose to sell the bonds prior to maturity.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What if I need cash but the current selling price for my bonds is not favourable?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">HSBC can offer you a loan at preferential rates of up to 70% the value of your bonds. Please consult us for details.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>How can I collect my interest payments?</strong><br> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">All bonds purchased through HSBC are under our custody and nominee service. So just sit back and we'll ensure all interest earned is credited to your settlement account once the payment is received from the relevant custodian on or after the coupon payment date.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What do Moody's and Standard and Poor's credit ratings represent?</strong><br> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">They refer to the ability of the bond issuer to repay the value and interest to bondholders. Moody's and Standard and Poor's are the best known international credit rating agencies. Ratings are assigned based on the bond issuer's financial strength and past record of debt repayment. In general, the higher the credit rating, the lower the risk of default and the interest offered.</p>
</div></div>

            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="content_main_richtext_8" class=" A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What are the risks in Bonds?</strong><br> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Bonds involves the following risks (including but not limited to): </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><br> Interest Rate Risks </p> 
<ul class="A-LSTU-RW-ALL"> 
 <li>Refers to the potential loss in the bond value as a result of a rise in term interest rate. However, there is no impact if planning to hold bond to maturity.</li> 
 <li>Causes of term interest rate increase can be central bank policy hike to manage inflation, increase in issuance size in a particular tenor and reduced demand in that tenor.</li> 
 <li>The longer the maturity of a bond, the higher the interest rate risk.</li> 
 <li>Bond investors can consider mitigating interest rate risk by investing in floating rate bonds/ notes.</li> 
</ul> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><br> Credit Risk <br> </p> 
<ul class="A-LSTU-RW-ALL"> 
 <li>Refers to the potential loss in the bond value as a result of either a downgrade of the issuer's credit rating or the market's perception of the issuer's credit worthiness and its ability to meet its financial obligations. However, there is no impact if planning to hold a bond to maturity.</li> 
 <li>Bond investors can consider mitigating credit risk by investing in bonds of higher risk rating.</li> 
</ul> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Default Risk</p> 
<ul class="A-LSTU-RW-ALL"> 
 <li>Refers to the potential total loss in the bond value as a result of the issuer going bankrupt.</li> 
 <li>Bond investors can consider mitigating credit risk by investing in bonds of higher risk rating.</li> 
</ul> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><br> Liquidity Risk <br> </p> 
<ul class="A-LSTU-RW-ALL"> 
 <li>Refers to investors may have difficulty finding a buyer when they want to sell and may be forced to sell at a significant discount to market value.</li> 
 <li>Liquidity risk is greater for thinly traded securities such as lower-rated bonds, bonds that were part of a small issue, bonds that have recently had their credit rating downgraded or bonds sold by an infrequent issuer. Bonds are generally the most liquid during the period right after issuance when the typical bond has the highest trading volume.</li> 
 <li>It is often reflected in wider spread between the bid and offer price of the bond.</li> 
</ul> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Will the bank provide me with regular statements of my Bond investment?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Yes, HSBC will provide contract note to you in every Bond transaction and you can also find your Bond investment record in the monthly consolidated statement (if applicable).</p>
</div></div>

    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Is the AAHK Retail Bonds guaranteed by the Government of Hong Kong?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">No. The obligations of AAHK to pay interest on the Retail Bonds and to repay the principal amount of the Retail Bonds at maturity are not guaranteed by the Government of Hong Kong.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Why is my allotted Retail Bonds holding in HSBC settled in CMU?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">According to the Offering Memorandum issued by AAHK, if the investor subscribes for the Retail Bonds via placing banks, the allotted Retail Bonds will be settled and held through Central Moneymarkets Unit (CMU), a debt securities custodian. The allotted Retail Bonds can be traded at Over-the Counter (OTC) through the Bank's Bond Trading Services.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Can I early redeem the allotted Retail Bonds before maturity date?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Yes. On each quarterly interest payment date of the Retail Bonds, bondholders have the right to redeem partial or all of the Bonds held at 100% of their principal amount together with accrued and unpaid interest to (but excluding) the date of redemption.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">For more details on the early redemption, please refer to Offering Memorandum.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Will I be informed of the early redemption period if I am holding the Retail Bonds with HSBC?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Yes. Early redemption Advice/ eAdvice will be sent to all bondholders upon notification from Central Monetary Unit (CMU). Bondholders can submit the early redemption instructions via completion of Corporate Action advice or HSBC Personal Internet Banking during the period for submission of early redemption instructions. Instruction is irrevocable.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Please note that after your Bonds are redeemed, you are no longer holding the Bonds and have no further rights under such Bonds and therefore not be entitled to receive any further payments on such Bonds.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>How can I sell the allotted Retail Bonds from IPO via HSBC for Over-the-Counter (OTC) trading?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">You can sell the allotted Retail Bonds instantly during trading hours through our OTC trading service, Online Bond Trading Services (click "Investments" on internet banking, then "Bonds/Certificates of Deposit", click "My portfolio") or Mobile Banking App (select “Sell” button under the bonds in your Portfoloio). You can also call our phonebanking or visit any branches for selling Bonds through our OTC Bond Trading Service. No extra fees and charges applied.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>If I want to sell the allotted Retail Bonds via Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEx), how can I do it?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">You can transfer the Retail Bonds to Central Clearing and Settlement System(CCASS) from Central Moneymarkets Unit (CMU) by filling in the transfer request form at branches. It normally takes 5 business days (for request received before noon) to complete the transfer before you can sell through HKEx. A transfer fee of HKD100 will be charged for any holding transfer between CMU and CCASS. The transfer fee is waived for any transfer of allotted Retail Bonds between CMU and CCASS from 5 February 2024 to 31 March 2024.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Selling of the Retail Bonds via the stock trading platform is subject to fees and charges of stock trading services, including brokerage fee, deposit charge (purchase order only), Securities and Futures Commission transaction levy, Financial Reporting Council transaction levy and Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited trading fee (details as illustrated below).</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>

    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What is the maximum allocation amount per investor?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">A maximum allocation amount of HK$1 million per investor is set on this Retail Infrastructure Bonds issuance. Hence, you will not be allotted in full if your application amount exceeds HK$1 million. Also, please note that you may be allocated with amount less than such maximum allocation amount.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>How can I sell the allotted HKSAR Government iBond/Retail Green Bonds/ Retail Infrastructure Bonds from IPO via HSBC for Over-the-Counter (OTC) trading?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">You can sell the allotted iBond/Retail Green Bonds/ Retail Infrastructure Bonds instantly during trading hours through our OTC trading service, Online Bond Trading Services (click "Investments" on internet banking, then "Bonds/Certificates of Deposit", click "My portfolio"). You can also call our phonebanking or visit any branches for selling of iBond/Retail Green Bonds/ Retail Infrastructure Bonds through our OTC Bond Trading Service. No extra fees and charges applied.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>If I want to sell the allotted iBond/Retail Green Bonds/ Retail Infrastructure Bonds via Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEx), how can I do it?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">You need to transfer the iBond/Retail Green Bonds/ Retail Infrastructure Bonds to Central Clearing and Settlement System(CCASS) by filling in a transfer request form at branches. It normally takes 5 business days (if request is received before noon) to complete the transfer before you can sell through HKEx. Please note the transfer fee is HKD100. (Such fee also applies for transfer from Central Clearing and Settlement System (CCASS) to Central Moneymarkets Unit (CMU).) The transfer fee is waived for any Retail Green Bonds holding transfer between Central Moneymarkets Unit (CMU) and Central Clearing and Settlement System (CCASS) from 17 December 2024 to 31 January 2025. Selling of the iBond /Retail Green Bonds/ Retail Infrastructure Bonds via the stock trading platform is subject to fees and charges of stock trading services including brokerage fee, deposit charge (purchase order only), Securities and Futures Commission transaction levy, Financial Reporting Council transaction levy, investor compensation levy (temporarily suspended by SFC at the date of issue circular) and Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited trading fee (details as illustrated below).</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>

<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>How can I transfer the allotted iBond/Retail Green Bonds/ Retail Infrastructure Bonds to Central Clearing and Settlement System(CCASS) for trading at Stock Exchange?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">You can visit any branch and fill in a transfer request form. It normally takes 5 business days to complete the transfer if request is received by the bank before noon. A service fee of HK$ 100 will be charged. (Such fee also applies for transfer from Central Clearing and Settlement System (CCASS) to Central Moneymarkets Unit (CMU).) The transfer fee is waived for any Retail Infrastructure Bonds holding transfer between Central Moneymarkets Unit (CMU) and Central Clearing and Settlement System (CCASS) from 17 December 2024 to 31 January 2025. Upon completion of transfer, the iBond/Retail Green Bonds/ Retail Infrastructure Bonds holding will be held under the respective stock code for trading via HKEx. </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Is there a price difference between the iBond/Retail Green Bonds/ Retail Infrastructure Bonds offered by the Bank's Bond Trading Services (or Over-The-Counter) and HKEx?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">You can trade iBond/Retail Green Bonds/ Retail Infrastructure Bonds through the following markets:</p>
<ol class="A-LSTO-RW-ALL">
 <li>Stock Exchange of Hong Kong</li>
 <li>OTC - over-the-counter, trading outside the Stock Exchange</li>
</ol>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">The price in the 2 markets may be different and there is chance that the price on HKEx is higher than OTC or vice versa. This is due to the different demand and supply in respective markets and that the price is driven by different market pool. The price gap also reflects the associated fee/levy when trading on HKEx.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">You should consider to trade in which market by considering the leadtime and all the associated costs (please refer to the above) besides the price.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What is the difference between iBond and Retail Infrastructure Bonds which also has the coupon rate linked to inflation rate?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Retail Infrastructure Bonds offers similar features to iBond, including interest rate which is linked to the inflation rate. The proceeds raised under Retail infrastructure bonds will be credited to the Capital Works Reserve Fund (“CWRF”) to provide funding for Government infrastructure projects. The Infrastructure Bond Programme (“IB Programme”) covers projects under the Government’s capital works programme of the CWRF (except for those that have been or are expected to be included in the Government Sustainable Bond Programme ("GSB Programme")), including projects under major infrastructure initiatives. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority assists the Government in implementing bond issuance under the IB Programme.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Is there additional risk for Retail Bonds as compared to that for iBond?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">As compared to iBond, investors need to note that the retail bonds may not necessarily be a suitable investment if you seek exposure to specific types of infrastructure projects. While the proceeds of the retail bonds will be used to fund one or more of the “Eligible Projects” as defined in the Infrastructure Bond Framework, payments under the retail bonds are not linked to the performance of the relevant Eligible Project(s). The retail bonds are not secured by income from the Eligible Project(s) and you do not have any rights to the Eligible Project(s). HKSAR Government has the sole and absolute discretion to determine the allocation of the proceeds of retail bonds to the Eligible Project(s), which may be changed and/or updated from time to time.</p>

    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Securities is the generic name for shares and other investment tools quoted on the stock market. Individuals may invest in securities, either through a broker or through their bank, and can check the progress of their investment every day in the newspapers or on the Internet.<br>
It is possible to enjoy a higher rate of return from investing in securities than from savings accounts. Stock market securities in thriving economic climates will generally show an increase over time, and sometimes within a very short period. However, all stock markets are volatile and buying securities should not be seen as a short-term method of making money.<br>
Buying securities also costs money. Stockbrokers make various charges for their services, such as commission. You may consider taking advantage of convenient payment and reimbursement terms by dealing through your bank. <br>
Other than investing in securities by yourself, you can assign asset management professionals or companies to invest on your behalf.<br>

    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>How can I place an order?</strong><br>
</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Simply call (852) 2233 3322. Speak to us after keying in your account number and PIN.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What information do I need to provide to place an order?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">The basic information required is the stock name, stock market, order size, your price limit and settlement currency. It is worth paying attention to the stock name. Using the full stock name in your order will ensure no misunderstanding on which stock to trade, as some stocks may have similar names. If in doubt, we will be happy to assist you based on your description of the abbreviated name, the nature of business and the latest closing price.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What order types are offered?</strong><br>
</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">We accept limit price orders. Orders placed will be valid for the same day until the respective market closes. You can place orders with us anytime. Orders received after the trading hours of the respective market will be processed on the next trading day.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>

    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>When will my account be debited for stock purchase?</strong><br> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Upon order placement (trade day), the purchase amount will be held on HKD/USD account. The actual debit of the money will take place on the settlement day (e.g. T+2, except Canada which is T+1 effective from 27 May 2024). Money held between the placement day and the settlement day will continue to earn interest in your account. In case the settlement day is a Hong Kong public holiday, the actual debit of the money will take place on the last working day before the settlement day. <br> If you choose to settle in USD and need to transfer sufficient funds into your USD settlement account, please do so before 7 p.m. Hong Kong time. We will be pleased to help you.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>How soon can I sell my stocks, and when will I receive the money from selling stocks?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Stocks can be sold once settlement is completed (i.e., T+2, except Canada which is T+1 effective from 27 May 2024). The sales proceeds will be credited to your account two days after the sales execution (i.e., T+2, except Canada which is T+1 effective from 27 May 2024). </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>How can I check the status of my Securities trading order?</strong><br> </p> 
<ul class="A-LSTU-RW-ALL"> 
 <li>HSBC Internet Banking<br> You can check your order status and execution result by clicking 'Checking order status' under 'My Investment' section. We will also notify you the execution result via email at HSBC Internet Banking.</li> 
 <li>Stock Express<br> You can check your order status under the 'Order Status' section. All securities orders with pending dealing status will be displayed first by default, but you can sort the sequence of display by stock code, transaction type and transaction date at your choice.</li> 
</ul> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Alternatively, you may also call our investment phonebanking services hotline or log on to HSBC Internet Banking to check your order status and execution result or sign up for our free eAlerts investment order confirmation service at HSBC Internet Banking to receive your stock order execution result via SMS. For more details about eAlerts, please go to 'Investment eAlerts' section at HSBC Internet Banking.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Can I trade my overseas securities during Hong Kong public holidays?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Trading will be available if overseas stock markets are open. We will be there to take your orders and answer your queries during Hong Kong public holidays.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Can I buy Nasdaq-Amex Pilot programs securities ('PP Securities') listed on Hong Kong Stock Exchange?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Effective from 1 Jan 2019, all buy orders for PP Securities listed on Hong Kong Stock Exchange will not be accepted due to insufficient liquidity in the Hong Kong market.<br> </p>

<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><sup>3</sup><em></em> Applicable to HSBC Premier customers only.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><sup>4 </sup>Stamp Duty, Transaction levies and HKEx Trading Fee, will be collected in RMB or HKD equivalent (according to official exchange rate ) for RMB denominated stock as determined by the bank, The bank may adopt some rounding measures in calculation of Transaction levies, Stamp Duty and HKEx Trading Fee, but will ensure that this never results in our customers paying more than the stated levy. The bank will also ensure that the correct levies will be paid to the relevant regulatory authorities<span style="font-family: "HSBC Univers Next Regular", "HSBC Neue Helvetica Regular"; font-size: 1rem; font-style: normal; font-weight: 400; background-color: transparent;">.</span></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><sup>5</sup><em></em> If there is more than one purchase transaction executed on a trading day (T) and/or the next following trading day (T+1), the sale transaction will first be matched with all purchase transactions executed on T based on their size, starting from the one with the largest quantity of purchased shares. After that, any unmatched sale shares will be matched with purchase transactions executed on T+1 based on their size, starting from the one with the largest quantity of purchased shares. Remaining shares of matched purchase transactions (if any) and/or unmatched purchase transactions (if any) are still subject to the deposit transaction charge with a minimum of HKD30/RMB30 for each purchase transaction.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><sup>6</sup><em></em> The charge applied is according to the transaction currency of the corporate action. For transaction currency other than HKD or RMB, HKD charge or equivalent at the Bank's prevailing exchange rate will be applied.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><sup>7</sup> Related charges of the above Hong Kong stocks services will also apply, where applicable.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">For non-HKD payment such as cash dividend, when respective currency account is not available/provided for the corporate action at the time of the payment, payment will be paid in Hong Kong Dollar equivalent at the Bank's prevailing exchange rate to customer's default HKD account after charge deduction.<br> </p>

            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="content_main_richtext_25" class=" A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">There may be other fees, charges, levies, tax and interest that apply to certain securities or particular security trading services provided by the Bank that are introduced and/or charged by the relevant service providers, government or regulatory bodies. The Customer is fully responsible for such fees, charges, levies, tax and interest. Please make enquiry with the Bank for details. <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">The Bank does not provide investment advice. Investment involves risk. The price of stocks may move up or down. Losses may be incurred as well as profits made as a result of buying and selling stocks. Full details of the terms and conditions of the above services are available on request.</p>

            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="content_main_richtext_26" class=" A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>How do I check my buying power for stock trading?</strong></p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">You can check your 'Account buying power' on HSBC Online Banking, the HSBC HK Easy Invest App and the HSBC HK Mobile Banking app. When you search for a stock, select the 'Buy' button, and see your 'Account buying power' on the buy order page after a settlement account is selected.<strong><br> <br> How do I submit Corporate Action instruction?</strong><br> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">You may submit your Corporate Action instruction by Personal Internet Banking or return reply slip to the Bank.<strong><br> <br> What risks are involved?</strong></p> 
<ol class="A-LSTO-RW-ALL"> 
 <li><strong>Risk of Securities Trading<br> <br> </strong>The prices of securities fluctuate, sometimes dramatically. The price of a security may move up or down, and may become valueless. It is as likely that losses will be incurred rather than profit made as a result of buying and selling securities.<strong><br> </strong></li> 
 <li><strong>Risk of Trading Futures and Options<br> <br> </strong>The risk of loss in trading futures contracts or options is substantial. In some circumstances, you may sustain losses in excess of your initial margin funds. Placing contingent orders, such as "stop-loss" or "stop-limit" orders, will not necessarily avoid loss. Market conditions may make it impossible to execute such orders. You may be called upon at short notice to deposit additional margin funds. If the required funds are not provided within the prescribed time, your position may be liquidated. You will remain liable for any resulting deficit in your account. You should therefore study and understand futures contracts and options before you trade and carefully consider whether such trading is suitable in the light of your own financial position and investment objectives. If you trade options you should inform yourself of exercise and expiration procedures and your rights and obligations upon exercise or expiry.<strong><br> </strong></li> 
 <li><strong>Risk of Trading Growth Enterprise Market Stocks<br> <br> </strong>Growth Enterprise Market (GEM) stocks involve a high investment risk. In particular, companies may list on GEM with neither a track record of profitability nor any obligation to forecast future profitability. GEM stocks may be very volatile and illiquid.<br> <br> You should make the decision to invest only after due and careful consideration. The greater risk profile and other characteristics of GEM mean that it is a market more suited to professional and other sophisticated investors.<br> <br> Current information on GEM stocks may only be found on the internet website operated by The Stock Exchange of Hong Kong Limited. GEM Companies are usually not required to issue paid announcements in gazetted newspapers.<br> <br> You should seek independent professional advice if you are uncertain of or have not understood any aspect of this risk disclosure statement or the nature and risks involved in trading of GEM stocks.<strong><br> </strong></li> 
 <li><strong>Risks of Client Assets Received or held outside Hong Kong<br> <br> </strong>Client assets received or held by the licensed or registered person outside Hong Kong are subject to the applicable laws and regulations of the relevant overseas jurisdiction which may be different from the Securities and Futures Ordinance (Cap.571) and the rules made thereunder.<br> Consequently, such client assets may not enjoy the same protection as that conferred on client assets received or held in Hong Kong.<br> </li> 
 <li><strong>Risk of Providing an Authority to repledge your Securities Collateral etc<br> <br> </strong>There is risk if you provide the licensed or registered person with an authority that allows it to apply your securities or securities collateral pursuant to a securities borrowing and lending agreement, repledge your securities collateral for financial accommodation or deposit your securities collateral as collateral for the discharge and satisfaction of its settlement obligations and liabilities.<br> <br> If your securities or securities collateral are received or held by the licensed or registered person in Hong Kong, the above arrangement is allowed only if you consent in writing. Moreover, unless you are a professional investor, your authority must specify the period for which it is current and be limited to not more than 12 months. If you are a professional investor, these restrictions do not apply.<br> <br> Additionally, your authority may be deemed to be renewed (i.e. without your written consent) if the licensed or registered person issues you a reminder at least 14 days prior to the expiry of the authority, and you do not object to such deemed renewal before the expiry date of your then existing authority.<br> <br> You are not required by any law to sign these authorities. But an authority may be required by licensed or registered persons, for example, to facilitate margin lending to you or to allow your securities or securities collateral to be lent to or deposited as collateral with third parties. The licensed or registered person should explain to you the purposes for which one of these authorities is to be used.<br> <br> If you sign one of these authorities and your securities or securities collateral are lent to or deposited with third parties, those third parties will have a lien or charge on your securities or securities collateral. Although the licensed or registered person is responsible to you for securities or securities collateral lent or deposited under your authority, a default by it could result in the loss of your securities or securities collateral.<br> <br> A cash account not involving securities borrowing and lending is available from most licensed or registered persons. If you do not require margin facilities or do not wish your securities or securities collateral to be lent or pledged, do not sign the above authorities and ask to open this type of cash account.<br> </li> 
 <li><strong>Risk of providing an authority to hold mail or to direct mail to third parties<br> <br> </strong>If you provide the licensed or registered person with an authority to hold mail or to direct mail to third parties, it is important for you to promptly collect in person all contract notes and statements of your account and review them in detail to ensure that any anomalies or mistakes can be detected in a timely fashion.<br> </li> 
 <li><strong>Risk of Margin Trading<br> <br> </strong>The risk of loss in financing a transaction by deposit of collateral is significant. You may sustain losses in excess of your cash and any other assets deposited as collateral with the licensed or registered person. Market conditions may make it impossible to execute contingent orders, such as "stop-loss" or "stop-limit" orders. You may be called upon at short notice to make additional margin deposits or interest payments. If the required margin deposits or interest payments are not made within the prescribed time, your collateral may be liquidated without your consent. Moreover, you will remain liable for any resulting deficit in your account and interest charged on your account. You should therefore carefully consider whether such a financing arrangement is suitable in light of your own financial position and investment objectives.<br> </li> 
 <li><strong>Risk of Trading Nasdaq-Amex Securities at The Stock Exchange of Hong Kong Limited<br> <br> </strong>The securities under the Nasdaq-Amex Pilot Program ("PP") are aimed at sophisticated investors. You should consult the licensed or registered person and become familiarised with the PP before trading in the PP securities. You should be aware that the PP securities are not regulated as a primary or secondary listing on the Main Board or the Growth Enterprise Market of The Stock Exchange of Hong Kong Limited.<br> </li> 
 <li><strong>Additional Risk Disclosure for Futures and Options Trading<br> <br> </strong>This brief statement does not disclose all of the risks and other significant aspects of trading in futures and options. In light of the risks, you should undertake such transactions only if you understand the nature of the contracts (and contractual relationships) into which you are entering and the extent of your exposure to risk. Trading in futures and options is not suitable for many members of the public. You should carefully consider whether trading is appropriate for you in light of your experience, objectives, financial resources and other relevant circumstances.<br> <br> 9.1 Futures<br> <br> (i) Effect of "Leverage" or "Gearing"<br> Transactions in futures carry a high degree of risk. The amount of initial margin is small relative to the value of the futures contract so that transactions are "leveraged" or "geared". A relatively small market movement will have a proportionately larger impact on the funds you have deposited or will have to deposit: this may work against you as well as for you. You may sustain a total loss of initial margin funds and any additional funds deposited with the firm to maintain your position. If the market moves against your position or margin levels are increased, you may be called upon to pay substantial additional funds on short notice to maintain your position. If you fail to comply with a request for additional funds within the time prescribed, your position may be liquidated at a loss and you will be liable for any resulting deficit.<br> <br> (ii) Risk-reducing orders or strategies<br> The placing of certain orders (e.g. "stop-loss" orders, or "stop-limit" orders) which are intended to limit losses to certain amounts may not be effective because market conditions may make it impossible to execute such orders. Strategies using combinations of positions, such as "spread" and "straddle" positions may be as risky as taking simple "long" or "short" positions.<br> <br> 9.2 Options<br> <br> (i) Variable degree of risk<br> <br> Transactions in options carry a high degree of risk. Purchasers and sellers of options should familiarise themselves with the type of option (i.e. put or call) which they contemplate trading and the associated risks. You should calculate the extent to which the value of the options must increase for your position to become profitable, taking into account the premium and all transaction costs.<br> <br> The purchaser of options may offset or exercise the options or allow the options to expire. The exercise of an option results either in a cash settlement or in the purchaser acquiring or delivering the underlying interest. If the option is on a futures contract, the purchaser will acquire a futures position with associated liabilities for margin (see the section on Futures above). If the purchased options expire worthless, you will suffer a total loss of your investment which will consist of the option premium plus transaction costs. If you are contemplating purchasing deep-out-of-the-money options, you should be aware that the chance of such options becoming profitable ordinarily is remote.<br> <br> Selling ("writing" or "granting") an option generally entails considerably greater risk than purchasing options. Although the premium received by the seller is fixed, the seller may sustain a loss well in excess of that amount. The seller will be liable for additional margin to maintain the position if the market moves unfavourably.<br> <br> The seller will also be exposed to the risk of the purchaser exercising the option and the seller will be obligated to either settle the option in cash or to acquire or deliver the underlying interest. If the option is on a futures contract, the seller will acquire a position in a futures contract with associated liabilities for margin (see the section on Futures above). If the option is "covered" by the seller holding a corresponding position in the underlying interest or a futures contract or another option, the risk may be reduced. If the option is not covered, the risk of loss can be unlimited.<br> <br> Certain exchanges in some jurisdictions permit deferred payment of the option premium, exposing the purchaser to liability for margin payments not exceeding the amount of the premium. The purchaser is still subject to the risk of losing the premium and transaction costs. When the option is exercised or expires, the purchaser is responsible for any unpaid premium outstanding at that time.<br> </li> 
 <li><strong>Additional Risks common to Futures and Options<br> </strong><br> 10.1 Terms and conditions of contracts<br> <br> You should ask the firm with which you deal about the terms and conditions of the specific futures or options which you are trading and associated obligations (e.g. the circumstances under which you may become obliged to make or take delivery of the underlying interest of a futures contract and, in respect of options, expiration dates and restrictions on the time for exercise). Under certain circumstances the specifications of outstanding contracts (including the exercise price of an option) may be modified by the exchange or clearing house to reflect changes in the underlying interest.<br> <br> 10.2 Suspension or restriction of trading and pricing relationships<br> <br> Market conditions (e.g. illiquidity) and/or the operation of the rules of certain markets (e.g. the suspension of trading in any contract or contract month because of price limits or "circuit breakers") may increase the risk of loss by making it difficult or impossible to effect transactions or liquidate/offset positions. If you have sold options, this may increase the risk of loss.<br> <br> Further, normal pricing relationships between the underlying interest and the futures, and the underlying interest and the option may not exist. This can occur when, for example, the futures contract underlying the option is subject to price limits while the option is not. The absence of an underlying reference price may make it difficult to judge "fair value".<br> <br> 10.3 Deposited cash and property<br> <br> You should familiarise yourself with the protections given to money or other property you deposit for domestic and foreign transactions, particularly in the event of a firm insolvency or bankruptcy. The extent to which you may recover your money or property may be governed by specific legislation or local rules. In some jurisdictions, property which had been specifically identifiable as your own will be pro-rated in the same manner as cash for purposes of distribution in the event of a shortfall.<br> <br> 10.4 Commission and other charges<br> <br> Before you begin to trade, you should obtain a clear explanation of all commission, fees and other charges for which you will be liable. These charges will affect your net profit (if any) or increase your loss.<br> <br> 10.5 Transactions in other jurisdictions<br> <br> Transactions on markets in other jurisdictions, including markets formally linked to a domestic market, may expose you to additional risk. Such markets may be subject to regulation which may offer different or diminished investor protection. Before you trade you should enquire about any rules relevant to your particular transactions. Your local regulatory authority will be unable to compel the enforcement of the rules of regulatory authorities or markets in other jurisdictions where your transactions have been effected. You should ask the firm with which you deal for details about the types of redress available in both your home jurisdiction and other relevant jurisdictions before you start to trade.<br> <br> 10.6 Currency risks<br> <br> The profit or loss in transactions in foreign currency-denominated contracts (whether they are traded in your own or another jurisdiction) will be affected by fluctuations in currency rates where there is a need to convert from the currency denomination of the contract to another currency.<br> <br> 10.7 Trading facilities<br> <br> Electronic trading facilities are supported by computer-based component systems for the order-routing, execution, matching, registration or clearing of trades. As with all facilities and systems, they are vulnerable to temporary disruption or failure. Your ability to recover certain losses may be subject to limits on liability imposed by the system provider, the market, the clearing house and/or participant firms. Such limits may vary: you should ask the firm with which you deal for details in this respect.<br> <br> 10.8 Electronic trading<br> <br> Trading on an electronic trading system may differ from trading on other electronic trading systems. If you undertake transactions on an electronic trading system, you will be exposed to risks associated with the system including the failure of hardware and software. The result of any system failure may be that your order is either not executed according to your instructions or is not executed at all.<br> <br> 10.9 Off-exchange transactions<br> <br> In some jurisdictions, and only then in restricted circumstances, firms are permitted to effect off-exchange transactions. The firm with which you deal may be acting as your counterparty to the transaction. It may be difficult or impossible to liquidate an existing position, to assess the value, to determine a fair price or to assess the exposure to risk. For these reasons, these transactions may involve increased risks. Off-exchange transactions may be less regulated or subject to a separate regulatory regime. Before you undertake such transactions, you should familiarise yourself with applicable rules and attendant risks.<br> </li> 
 <li><strong>Risk of Trading Warrants and Callable Bull/Bear Contracts<br> <br> </strong>Warrants and Callable Bull/Bear Contracts (CBBCs) are structured products which involve derivatives.<br> <br> You rely on the creditworthiness of the issuer of warrants and/or CCBCs. Subject to both the actual and perceived measures of the credit worthiness of its issuer and, there is no assurance of protection against a default by its issuer in respect of its payment obligations. Upon insolvency of the issuer, you may get nothing back and the potential maximum loss could be 100% of the investment amount and no return may be received.<br> <br> You are warned that the prices of warrants and CBBCs may fall in value as rapidly as it may rise and holders may sustain a total loss of their investment. CBBCs have a mandatory call feature and may therefore be subject to early termination, upon which (i) investors in category N CBBCs will lose all of their investments in the CBBCs; and (ii) the residual value of category R CBBCs may be zero.<br> <br> Before you purchase any warrants and/or CBBCs, you should ensure you understand the nature of warrants and/or CBBCs and carefully study the full details and risk factors set out in the relevant listing documents and, where necessary, seek professional advice before you invest in any of these products. You should also ensure that you fully understand the potential risks and rewards and independently determine that they are appropriate for you given your objectives, experience, financial and operational resources and other relevant circumstances. You should note that The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation Limited acting through its appointed liquidity provider may be the only market participant in HSBC-issued warrants and CBBCs.<br> </li> 
</ol>

<h3 class="heading A-TYP16R-RW-ALL " id="content_main_heading_9">
    What are securities?
</h3>
</div>

        
    
        
        
            
            
            
            
            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="content_main_richtext_27" class=" A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Securities is the generic name for shares and other investment tools quoted on the stock market. Individuals may invest in securities, either through a broker or through their bank, and can check the progress of their investment every day in the newspapers or on the Internet.<br> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">It is possible to enjoy a higher rate of return from investing in securities than from savings accounts. Stock market securities in thriving economic climates will generally show an increase over time, and sometimes within a very short period. However, all stock markets are volatile and buying securities should not be seen as a short-term method of making money.<br> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Buying securities also costs money. Stockbrokers make various charges for their services, such as commission. You may consider taking advantage of convenient payment and reimbursement terms by dealing through your bank.<br> </p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Other than investing in securities by yourself, you can assign asset management professionals or companies to invest on your behalf.</p>

            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="content_main_richtext_28" class=" A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What information do I need to provide to place an order?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">The basic information required is the stock name, stock market, order size, your price limit and settlement currency. It is worth paying attention to the stock name. Using the full stock name in your order will ensure no misunderstanding on which stock to trade, as some stocks may have similar names. If in doubt, we will be happy to assist you based on your description of the abbreviated name, the nature of business and the latest closing price.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Can I set an expiry date for my order?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">You can set a future date (up to 7 calendar days) as the expiry date when you place an order (except at-auction order and market order). If your order is not fully executed at market close on the day you place your order, the unfilled order quantity (in whole or in part) will be pending for execution again at your specified price on the next trade day and each following trade day until the order quantity is filled or until the expiry date.<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Brokerage fee is charged on the order amount executed each day according to the Securities Services charges table. Please note the minimum brokerage fee.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>(Effective from October 2024) How much fund should I hold in my settlement account after I have placed a buy order for HK Stock?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Please ensure that your settlement account has sufficient funds to settle your executed buy orders.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Limit Order:<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Estimated total = Limit price x quantity x 101% + fees and charges (where applicable)<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Market Order:<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">During Pre-Opening Session: 115% x Previous closing / listing price for newly listed stocks x quantity + fees and charges (where applicable)<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">During Continuous Trading Session: (Ask price + 9 spreads) x quantity + fees and charges (where applicable)<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">During Closing Auction Session: 105% x Last trade price x quantity + fees and charges (where applicable)</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">The actual settlement amount will be calculated and debited from your settlement account on T+2 by our system. Please note that the actual settlement amount may be greater than or lower than the amount calculated based on formulas above.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>How do I deposit my HK stock physical certificate into my HSBC investment account?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">If you would deposit your HK stock physical certificate into your HSBC investment account, you may visit any one of the designated branches in-person as shown below:</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL" style="margin-left: 40.0px;">1.    Hong Kong Office                 Level 3, 1 Queen's Road Central, Central, HK</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL" style="margin-left: 40.0px;">2.    Exchange Square Branch     Shop 102, 1/F, Exchange Square Podium, Central, HK</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL" style="margin-left: 40.0px;">3.    North Point Branch              G/F, Winner House, 306-316 King's Road, North Point, HK</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL" style="margin-left: 40.0px;">4.    Mong Kok Branch                U/G, 673 Nathan Road, Mong Kok, KLN</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL" style="margin-left: 40.0px;">5.    Tsim Sha Tsui Branch          UG/F, 82-84 Nathan Road, Tsim Sha Tsui, KLN</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL" style="margin-left: 40.0px;">6.    Kwun Tong Branch              G/F, Wong Tze Building, 71 Hoi Yuen Road, Kwun Tong, KLN</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL" style="margin-left: 40.0px;">7.    Yuen Long Branch               G/F, HSBC Building Yuen Long, 150-160 Castle Peak Rd, Yuen Long, NT</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL" style="margin-left: 40.0px;">8.    Tsuen Wan Branch              Shop Nos. 4A, 4B(A)-4B(C),5&6, Fou Wah Centre, 210 Castle Peak Road, Tsuen Wan, NT</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL" style="margin-left: 40.0px;">9.    Tai Po Branch                    G/F, 54-58 Kwong Fuk Road, Tai Po, NT</p>

            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="content_main_richtext_29" class=" A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What is Severe Weather Trading?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">After the Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEx) implemented Severe Weather Trading (starting from 23 September 2024), Hong Kong securities and derivatives markets remain open during trading days with severe weather conditions, such as where a Typhoon Signal No.8 or above and/or a Black Rainstorm Warning is issued by the Hong Kong Observatory, or if an "extreme conditions" announcement is made by the HKSAR Government. More details about Severe Weather Trading can be found from the website of HKEx.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What is the trading arrangement on a Severe Weather Trading day in Hong Kong?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">On a Severe Weather Trading day: (1) the HKEx will maintain trading, post-trade and listing arrangements in its securities and derivatives markets; (2) you can trade HK and China Connect Securities and/or apply for a HK IPO via HSBC HK Mobile Banking App, HSBC HK Easy Invest App, HSBC HK Online Banking or our phone banking service (where applicable); and (3) you can transfer funds online to your settlement account (note that you may need to adjust your transfer limits in advance to meet your trading needs, and settlement or margin obligations if applicable). To ensure safety, our branches in Hong Kong will be closed.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Please note that physical scrip deposit / withdrawal and stock transfer services will not be available on a Severe Weather Trading day.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What should I pay attention to regarding the Securities Margin Trading Service on a Severe Weather Trading day in Hong Kong?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Please note that you could still be subject to a margin call or forced liquidation of securities on a Severe Weather Trading day.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Will trade settlement take place on a Severe Weather Trading day in Hong Kong?</strong><br> <br> Yes, trade settlement will take place on a Severe Weather Trading Day. Please ensure that you have sufficient funds in your settlement account to meet your settlement obligations.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What should I pay attention to regarding Corporate Actions handling services on a Severe Weather Trading Day in Hong Kong?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Corporate actions will be processed in accordance with the Hong Kong Securities Clearing Company Limited (HKSCC)’s arrangement. For example :</p>
<ul class="A-LSTU-RW-ALL">
 <li>Cash dividend distribution will be paid upon receipt of fund via HKSCC on the same day</li>
 <li>Stock dividend and bonus issue may be processed on the next business day according to distribution via HKSCC</li>
 <li>Stock consolidation and splitting, and change in board lot size of stock will be processed as scheduled</li>
</ul>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">More details of corporate actions arrangements on a Severe Weather Trading day in Hong Kong can be found from the website of the Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Please ensure that you have sufficient funds in your settlement account to meet your settlement obligations.</p>
</div></div>

<h3 class="heading A-TYP16R-RW-ALL " id="content_main_heading_10">

</h3>
</div>

        
    
        
        
            
            
            
            
            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="content_main_richtext_30" class=" A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Customers are eligible for signing up for the U.S. Stock Trading Service if they are<br> </p> 
<ul class="A-LSTU-RW-ALL"> 
 <li>Non-U.S. persons</li> 
 <li>Able to provide a valid identification document such as permanent Hong Kong Identity Card or passport.</li> 
 <li>Non professional market data subscribers<a><sup>*</sup></a> (Please refer to the <a href="/content/dam/hsbc/hk/docs/investments/market-information/didplay-services-agreement.pdf">NYSE Market Data Agreement [PDF].</a> for details.)</li> 
</ul> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><em></em><sup>*</sup> One of the criteria for being classified as 'Non-professional' subscribers is not being engaged as an investment advisor. In brief, "Investment adviser" means any person who, for compensation, engages in the business of advising others, either directly or through publications or writings, as to the value of securities or as to the advisability of investing, purchasing, or selling securities, or who, for compensation and as part of a regular business, issues or promulgates analyses or reports concerning securities.</p>

            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="content_main_richtext_31" class="remove-bottom-space A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What is product and service coverage for the US Stock Trading Service?</strong><br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">HSBC's US Stock Trading Service provides trading and custodian services for US stocks listed in NYSE (NYSE Equities Market), NASDAQ and AMEX (NYSE Amex Equities Market). Non-listed US securities are beyond our service scope.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>How do I register for the US Stock Trading Service?</strong></p>
<ol class="A-LSTO-RW-ALL">
 <li>Open an investment services account (with account suffix 380) with HSBC by visiting any HSBC branch or via <a href="https://www.hsbc.com.hk/online/dashboard" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span aria-hidden="true">HSBC Internet Banking.</span><span class="visuallyhidden">HSBC Internet Banking.  This link will open in a new window</span></a> (for existing HSBC's customers only) if you do not have one</li>
 <li>Visit the HSBC Stock Trading Browser or use your Easy Invest mobile app to complete the W-8BEN substitute form, as well as the agreement for market data display services. After you've submitted the forms, do note it will take at least 2 business days (excluding Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays) for us to process your information.</li>
</ol>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Note: Please seek your own independent professional advice for filling out the W-8BEN form and the NYSE Market Data Agreement where necessary.<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What is the W-8BEN form?</strong><br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">The <a href="/content/dam/hsbc/hk/docs/investments/stocks/us-stock-trading/w8ben-form.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span aria-hidden="true">W-8BEN form [PDF]</span><span class="visuallyhidden">W-8BEN form [PDF]  This link will open in a new window</span></a> (should submit together with the <a href="/content/dam/hsbc/hk/tc/docs/investments/stocks/us-stock-trading/return-sheet.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span aria-hidden="true">Return Sheet [PDF]</span><span class="visuallyhidden">Return Sheet [PDF]  This link will open in a new window</span></a>) is a requirement of the U.S. Internal Revenue Service ("IRS") for U.S. tax reporting for non-U.S. persons. Non-U.S. persons are subject to U.S. tax (max 30%) on certain types of income received from U.S. sources, such as interest and dividends. (<a href="https://www.hsbc.com.hk/pws/Components/personal/assets/pdf/GCW-8BEN_form.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span aria-hidden="true">Guidance for Completion of W-8BEN form [PDF]</span><span class="visuallyhidden">Guidance for Completion of W-8BEN form [PDF]  This link will open in a new window</span></a>)</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Non-U.S. persons are required to complete and submit a duly completed W-8BEN Form for the following main reasons</p>
<ul class="A-LSTU-RW-ALL">
 <li>to establish that you are not a U.S. person; and</li>
 <li>to claim that you are the beneficiary of the US-sourced income for which the W-8BEN Form is provided; and</li>
 <li>to claim, if applicable, a reduced rate of, or exemption from, withholding tax by being a resident of a foreign country/region with which the United States has an income tax treaty.</li>
</ul>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">If you would like to know more about the instructions for Form W-8BEN and tax treaties, please visit the following IRS websites or consult your tax adviser:<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Instructions for Form W-8BEN:</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><a href="http://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/iw8ben.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span aria-hidden="true">http://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/iw8ben.pdf [PDF]</span><span class="visuallyhidden">http://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/iw8ben.pdf [PDF]  This link will open in a new window</span></a></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Tax Treaties Information: </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><a href="https://www.irs.gov/individuals/international-taxpayers/tax-treaty-tables" style="font-family: "HSBC Univers Next Regular" , Arial , "PingFang SC" , "Microsoft YaHei" , "Lantinghei SC" , "Heiti SC" , simhei , sans-serif; font-variant: inherit;">https://www.irs.gov/individuals/international-taxpayers/tax-treaty-tables</a><span style="font-family: "HSBC Univers Next Regular" , Arial , "PingFang SC" , "Microsoft YaHei" , "Lantinghei SC" , "Heiti SC" , simhei , sans-serif; font-variant: inherit; line-height: 1.5; background-color: transparent;"></span></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What is the NYSE Market Data Agreement?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">The <a href="/content/dam/hsbc/hk/docs/investments/market-information/didplay-services-agreement.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span aria-hidden="true">NYSE Market Data Agreement [PDF]</span><span class="visuallyhidden">NYSE Market Data Agreement [PDF]  This link will open in a new window</span></a>, also known as "Exhibit B Agreement For Market Data Display Services", relates to provision of market data by the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE). As required by NYSE, every HSBC customer must sign this agreement to confirm that he/she is a "non-professional" market data subscriber before obtaining access to the NYSE's market data.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>When is the settlement day for US stocks transaction?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Effective from 28 May 2024, settlement day of US securities market is 1 business day after trade execution day (T+1). Clearance and settlement of US stocks buy and sales orders will take place on the 1st business day after trade execution day.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>(Effective from October 2024) How much fund should I hold in my settlement account after I have placed a buy order for US Stock?</strong> </p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Please ensure that your settlement account has sufficient funds to settle your executed buy orders.<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Limit Order:<br> Estimated total = Limit price x quantity x 101% + fees and charges (where applicable)<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Market Order:<br> During continuous trading: Estimated total = Limit up price*   x quantity + fees and charges (where applicable)<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">During trading halt: Estimated total = 115% x Maximum (Previous closing or Last trade price   before trading halt) x quantity + fees and charges (where applicable)<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">The actual settlement amount will be calculated and debited from your settlement account on T+1   by our system. Please note that the actual settlement amount may be greater than or lower than the amount calculated based on formulas above.</p>
</div></div>

            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="content_main_richtext_37" class=" A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Under what circumstances will the purchase of SSE and SZSE securities not be accepted?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Investors will not be able to buy SSE and SZSE securities under certain circumstances, which includes, but not limited to:<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">a) the SSE and SZSE securities cease to be a constituent stock of the relevant indices;</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">b) the SSE and SZSE securities are under "risk alert";</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">c) the corresponding H share of the SSE and SZSE securities cease to be traded on SEHK;</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">d) the Daily Quota Balance drops to zero or is exceeded;</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">e) where foreign investors hold more than a specified level of the SSE and SZSE securities;</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">f) whenever the HKEx determines that it is appropriate and in the interest of a fair and orderly market to protect investors;</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">g) hoisting of a Typhoon Signal No. 8 or above or the issuance of the Black Rainstorm Warning in Hong Kong;</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">h) investors fail to provide information as requested by relevant regulator.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">i) shares not traded in RMB</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Investors are advised to refer to the HKEx website and the SFC website relating to Shanghai and Shenzhen Stock Connect as updated from time to time and other relevant sources for detailed information.<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Why is my China A/ China B stock order being rejected or not sent to exchange for execution ?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">When we, HSBC (or its relevant broker) submits your order to an exchange, we do so in an orderly manner and in comply with any applicable local regulation/exchange trading rules/market requirements. Under certain circumstances, for example, if your order requested price is away from where the security is trading or if the order is particularly large to the market, we may need to reject the order without prior notice to you to ensure the market integrity and protect your interest. For China A stock, if your order is rejected, the order status will change to ‘unexecuted’ within the ‘Order Status’ enquiry. Please be reminded to check the latest order status. For China B stock, you may call our Premier Elite Dedicated Service Line on <a href="tel:+852-2233-3033" class="no-link" role="presentation">(852) 2233 3033</a> or Premier Customers Hotline on <a href="tel:+852-2233-3322" class="no-link" role="presentation">(852) 2233 3322</a> to check the latest order status.<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">In situations where we need to contact you to confirm the order details, we will not place your order to the exchange for execution until clarification is obtained.<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Can I subscribe for Shanghai or Shenzhen A Stock initial public offering (IPO)?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">According to HKEx, it is not currently contemplated that ShanghaiHong Kong and Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect will support initial public offering (IPO).</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Where can I obtain more information on Shanghai–Hong Kong and Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">For latest details and further info, please visit the dedicated Stock Connect homepage of HKEx.<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>How can I obtain the latest company announcement?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">All approved corporate actions on SSE and SZSE Securities will be announced by the issuers through the SSE and SZSE websites respectively and four officially appointed newspapers (both the printed paper and their websites): the Shanghai Securities News, Securities Times, China Securities Journal and Securities Daily. Hong Kong and overseas investors can visit the SSE, SZSE and newspaper websites for the latest listed company announcements.<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">You can also visit HKEx website’s China Stock Markets Web for the company announcements of SSE and SZSE Securities issued on the previous trading day.<br></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Hong Kong and overseas investors trading SSE and SZSE Securities through Shanghai-Hong Kong and Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect should note that SSE and SZSE listed issuers will continue to publish corporate documents in Chinese only as their current practice, and English translation will not be available.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What is Severe Weather Trading?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">After the Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEx) implemented Severe Weather Trading (starting from 23 September 2024), Hong Kong securities and derivatives markets remain open during trading days with severe weather conditions, such as where a Typhoon Signal No.8 or above and/or a Black Rainstorm Warning is issued by the Hong Kong Observatory, or if an "extreme conditions" announcement is made by the HKSAR Government. More details about Severe Weather Trading can be found from the website of HKEx.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What is the trading arrangement on a Severe Weather Trading day in Hong Kong?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">On a Severe Weather Trading day: (1) the HKEx will maintain trading, post-trade and listing arrangements in its securities and derivatives markets; (2) you can trade HK and China Connect Securities and/or apply for a HK IPO via HSBC HK Mobile Banking App, HSBC HK Easy Invest App, HSBC HK Online Banking or our phone banking service (where applicable); and (3) you can transfer funds online to your settlement account (note that you may need to adjust your transfer limits in advance to meet your trading needs, and settlement or margin obligations if applicable). To ensure safety, our branches in Hong Kong will be closed.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Please note that stock transfer services will not be available on a Severe Weather Trading day.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>Will trade settlement take place on a Severe Weather Trading day in Hong Kong?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Yes, trade settlement will take place on a Severe Weather Trading Day. Please ensure that you have sufficient funds in your settlement account to meet your settlement obligations.</p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"><strong>What should I pay attention to regarding Corporate Actions handling services on a Severe Weather Trading Day in Hong Kong ?</strong></p>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Corporate actions will be processed in accordance with the Hong Kong Securities Clearing Company Limited (HKSCC)’s arrangement. For example :</p>
<ul class="A-LSTU-RW-ALL">
 <li>Cash dividend distribution will be paid upon receipt of fund via HKSCC on the same day</li>
 <li>Stock dividend and bonus issue may be processed on the next business day according to distribution via HKSCC</li>
 <li>Stock consolidation and splitting, and change in board lot size of stock will be processed as scheduled</li>
</ul>
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">More details of corporate actions arrangements on a Severe Weather Trading day in Hong Kong can be found from the website of the Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited.</p>
</div></div>
